Award.AwardTitle: Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the thirty-fourth Southeastern-Atlantic Regional Conference on Differential Equations (SEARCDE) conference, held at the University of Memphis in Memphis, TN on October 11 and 12, 2014. The SEARCDE, initiated by members of the Department of Mathematics at the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, has met annually since 1981. Since then, the meeting has rotated among various research institutions in the Southeast. The primary objective of SEARCDE is to promote research and education in the field of differential equations by bringing together established and beginning researchers, including advanced undergraduate and graduates students as well as recent PhDs. In addition to the four plenary lectures given by outstanding internationally recognized scholars, there are twenty minute contributed talks given in parallel sessions. SEARCDE provides opportunities for all participants to present their own work in these twenty minute contributed talks. The sessions are organized so that talks by established researchers are interspersed with talks by beginning researchers. Detailed information about the conference can be found at the conference's website, http://www.searcde.org .

The principal goal of the SEARCDE meeting is to provide a platform to exchange ideas, to discuss recent developments in the field, and to provide important opportunities for networking and the creation of new research collaborations. The meeting provides a platform to exchange ideas and to discuss recent developments in both theoretical and applied differential equations. SEARCDE particularly encourages the participation of beginning researchers who get to meet and hear renowned plenary speakers plus leading regional experts. This typically has led to new contacts, collaboration opportunities, and broader interests. These features are important for young researchers, especially those from traditionally underrepresented groups. For the past three decades, SEARCDE has been the setting for many talks given by graduate students on the topics of their dissertation research. Often this is their first experience giving a formal conference presentations. NSF funding ensures that many talented young researchers will have the opportunity to participate in SEARCDE 2014.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objective of the Southeastern Atlantic Regional Conference in Differential Equations (SEARCDE) is to promote research and education in the field of differential equations by bringing together established and beginning researchers, including advanced undergraduate and graduates students as well as recent PhD’s. The meeting provides a platform to exchange ideas and to discuss recent developments in the field. SEARCDE particularly encourages the participation of beginning researchers, for whom the opportunities offered by conferences including regional experts are important, especially for those from traditionally under represented groups. This meeting provides opportunities for all participants to present their own work in twenty minute contributed talks. The sessions are such that talks by established researchers are interspersed with talks by beginning researchers. For the past three decades, SEARCDE has been the setting for many talks given by graduate students on the topics of their dissertation research. Often this is their first experience giving formal conference presentations.

    Although a first talk given by a beginning researcher to an unfamiliar audience can often be accompanied by anxiety, the friendly atmosphere of this particular conference provides the ideal setting for a first research talk by a graduate or an advanced undergraduate student. Feedback from the audience is constructive and is often followed by a private conversation between the student speaker and one or more of those in the audience whose interest was aroused by the student's presentation. The opportunities provided by these conferences for beginning researchers to make new acquaintances with both more experienced researchers and other young researchers working in their areas is essential for ensuring the seamless continuation of research in differential equations from one generation to the next, and thus in ensuring the continued maintenance of a network of scholars in the field.  

    The thirty-fourth SEARCDE conference was held at the University of Memphis (UM) in Memphis, TN on October 11 and 12, 2014.  The conference consisted of four one hour plenary lectures by the internationally recognized scholars listed below and concurrent sessions of contributed talks. The four plenary speakers were G. Paolo Galdi (University of Pittsburgh), Andrea Nahmod (University of Massasschusetts Amherst), Gieri Simonett (Vanderbilt University) , and Michael Taylor (University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill).

    With 124 registered participants, this was one of the largest if not the largest SEARCDE meeting ever held.  Without a doubt, the support of the NSF grant was a major contributing factor to its success.  With travel budgets at most universities being continually cut, NSF support is critical to young researchers who do not have adequate resources from their universities to attend conferences at the outset of their careers. The organizers worked hard to recruit a diverse group of participants and were successful in doing so.
